title: Has any war simply stopped because of a country's inability to pay for it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most major conflicts of the 20th century have ended because 2 things happened: The money ran out Or  The will to fight ran out Rarely did people actually completely get conquered or destroyed. The Nazi's were actually one of the few exceptions,. World war 1 and Nazi Germany both were two sides of the same penny: the economy was collapsing, however in WW2, the Germans were losing badly against Russia in the end, who in turn got heavy material support from the allies. Manpower was pretty much the only thing Russia had in spades Some people say they were conquered because of the Holocaust and the atrocities they committed. Sadly this isn't true: people have committed genocide in so many countries, nobody rarely intervenes unless there's a more compelling incentive to do so(even to this day! Darfur only a few years ago, it barely made the news. Cambodia under the Khmer Rouge?).  The Allied invasion of WW2 pretty much only assured that half of Europe wouldn't be conquered by Russia because at that point, Germany was already pretty much defeated from the grand strategic point of view. And the Nazi's were in a bad spot politically and geographically. The real enemy of WW2 for America was Russia, sadly enough. Churchill was very weary of peace with the Russians, and Stalin was not happy with the outcome of world war 2. He wanted Europe from the start and didn't get it. But the population wouldn't stand for more fighting after a conflict like that. The powers that be had no choice but to stop the fight, despite their ambitions. Japan surrendered in WW2 without any allied troops setting foot on Japan itself (well, you know what I mean). Again, the will to fight was gone because the bomb made clear it was no longer worthwhile fighting. However, some Japanese generals wanted to fight even after the second bomb... Goes to show how extreme their will was on this. Afterwards, the cold war ended again, simply because Russia's economy collapsed because of internal factors. Not because of military intervention. Bad economic management combined with rampant corruption destroyed the soviet union. Vietnam was over, not so much because of heavy military defeats, but because the public support completely dried up in the US after the tet offensive. Actually, the US pretty much never lost a battle of significance of the Vietnam war, and severly outspent the other side too. But the people were rising up against the conflict. And more recently: Desert storm ended simply because they no longer saw Saddam as a threat and he kept selling us cheap oil. The official reason was that we didn't have a UN mandate to go into Iraq. But the powers that be had made their point to Saddam. And for a while at least, he complied. The Korean war never actually ended and is the longest running conflict in the 20th century between industrialized nations, I think. Both still have money and will to fight... This will probably continue until North Korea collapses economically.

Interesting question.  From the answers it would not seem so; after all, money can always be "printed"... Perhaps it is not a matter of a lack of actual money (after all the future of a nation is at stake - so what relevance is paper money. To the Japanese in WW2, money was not the issue at all... ) but rather the level of accrued debt... I have often reflected on the two atomic bombs dropped on Japan. Conventional history states that the Allies justified using  the weapons to save Allied lives from any land invasion - and citing the fierceness of the fighting for Iwo Jima and Okinawa to back this up.  However there was a history programme (can't recall which) some years ago that revealed something far more interesting.  It is important to note that the US Government was bankrolling their Allies' - and their own - campaign in the European theatre and keeping them (and themselves) going in Asia/Pacific - not to mention the various R&D programs (inc. the A/H-bombs) happening in the US.  As such the US government was rapidly depleting the economy so much they were in danger of no longing being able to sell War bonds to continue the war's funding as they closed-in on the Japanese Home Islands. In effect the US government was itself close to full bankruptcy, which is what the Japanese were actually counting on to literally stop the US Army in its tracks. However with the timely completion of the Manhattan Project, the Allies were provided the ideal opportunity for the end of WW2 proper; not only to save US/Allied military lives but more so to prevent the US itself being financially bled-dry and having to negotiate a settlement with Imperial Japan.

The American Revolution. The cost of the war was ruinous to Great Britain, because it was fighting not only its own colonies, but also France, Spain, and the Netherlands, and those three nations were taking the fight to the British all over the world, not just in America. George III was having to convey soldiers (many of them Hessian mercenaries who were costing him money) across 3,000 miles of ocean and maintain expensive garrisons in a vast expanse of hostile territory. The British had also lost the benefit of trade with their rebellious colonies, not to mention with the nations they were at war with. The major business interests in the country wanted peace, so they could resume nornal trade, even if it meant dealing with an independent USA.  After the surrender at Yorktown, the second time a large British colonial army had surrendered en masse during the war, Parliament forced George III to negotiate for peace by refusing to appropriate any more money for him to prosecute the war.  The same thing very nearly occurred in the Seven Years' War, when Britain was funding Frederick the Great's war effort. As the war wound down, they warned Frederick that their country's ability to keep fighting France, and fund Prussia's war against basically every other power on the European continent at the same time, was at an end. Frederick was saved from having to accept a harsh peace treaty when Tsarina Elizabeth of Russia died, and her successor made peace with Prussia. The Prussians then turned their whole army on Austria and compelled it to accept peace status quo ante bellum.

World War I. Germany didn't run out of soldiers. It ran out of money and supplies. By the end of the war, the Allies (now with massive American industrial, personnel and financial backing) was outspending the Central Powers by triple.  In all of the war, the British Empire-Dominion spent about $40 billion (1918, USD). In less than two years of war, the US spent a whopping $23 billion. Whereas in the four years of war, Germany spent $37 billion, France spent $24 billion, Austria-Hungary spent $21 billion, Russia spent $22 billion (and exited the war a year early). In the end, the Allies outspent the Axis by double ($125B / $61B).  As the war came to a close, Central Powers were literally falling apart (Austria-Hungary and Ottoman Empire). Some of their constituent subdivisions had declared independence and had set up local governments. Germany ran out of money and motivation. By the end, her wartime industrial production was half what it was the day Germany entered the war, most contracts were going unpaid as the government was out of Papiermark to pay them (or rather, the hyperinflation on the Papiermark was rendering it useless and there was no "hard currency" to pay the bills).

Not that I know of.  Wartime governments usually have unlimited power to take whatever they need, and most citizens go along with this.  They also can and do build up huge financial debts, and sometimes their credit gets strained.  But they can usually borrow from somewhere. In World War One, Germany had run out of resources, not money as such.  There were no more men to send and the German army was in retreat.  There was also mass hunger because of the Allied sea blockade.  (Which however was contined, with great loss of life, until Germany signed up to a very unfair peace.) German in 1918 also faced popular uprisings and mutinies by soldiers and sailors.

All wars technically end because of a country's inability to pay for it.  When you stop paying the soldiers to fight or the scientists to research better weapons, the war ends (for you).  It may not be immediate end, but it is the key factor that results in a countries eventual defeat.  Most strategy in war is to make it too costly for your opponent to fight anymore,  that means reducing their economic capacity to build weapons, supply their troops or pay their existing troops to throw their lives away.

I don't think money is the main trasom Why the war started. You cannot blame the cards that people are playing poker or gambling. There's something much worse hiding behind money. It is called greed and selfishness. There are giye main types of money today: 1) real, honestly earned money, 2) stolen money 3) fake money and 4) money created out of nothing by the World Bank
